title: Introduction to pleior
text: Clean data filter genome-wide significance:
code: # Filter for genome-wide significant associations (p < 5e-8) gwas_clean <- preprocess_gwas(     gwas_subset,     pvalue_threshold = 5e-8 )  cat("After filtering:", nrow(gwas_clean), "significant associations\n")

title: Pleiotropy Analysis for GWAS Data
text: package designed analyze pleiotropy genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Pleiotropy occurs single genetic variant influences multiple traits, offering insights shared biological pathways disease relationships. package enables users identify, analyze, visualize pleiotropic associations, addressing question genetic variants contribute multiple complex traits, Alzheimer’s disease related conditions.

title: Pleiotropy Analysis for GWAS Data
text: Understanding pleiotropy crucial uncovering shared biological mechanisms, explaining disease comorbidity, identifying potential therapeutic targets. However, existing tools pleiotropy analysis often fragmented, focusing specific aspects like detection visualization, may lack user-friendly interfaces integration functional annotations. Recent research suggests pleiotropy widespread human genetics, many genetic variants linked multiple diseases traits. example, SNP (rs814573) known associated Alzheimer’s disease traits like myocardial infarction tyrosine measurement. Understanding connections help explain certain diseases co-occur (co-morbidity) identify potential targets responses treatment/drug based shared genetic predispositions known traits. pleior provides unified platform explore relationships, making easier generate hypotheses interpret results. 2019 study Nature Genetics found trait-associated loci cover half genome, 90% overlapping multiple traits. Similarly, studies like FactorGo (2023) PLACO (2020) emphasize need scalable, statistically robust methods characterize pleiotropy across thousands traits. pleior builds findings providing unified toolset explore pleiotropy practical, accessible manner.
